div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: WEDNKDAY, MARCH 29, 1905.

div.head: THE ALLIANCE.
div.p: Our telegrams announce that the "Daily Telegraph" is advocating the$ strengthening of the Anglo-Japanese alliance, and wo are told that this policy of our London contemporary is receiving general approbation in the City. Our present treaty with Japan may be taken to express the accepted policy as far as concerns the matters with which it deals, by Great Britain recognizes Japan's. Chinas her special interests in Mauchuna, aid her right to take steps to protect them it stipulates that if in the protector oi time interests Japan should at war with a third Power Great Britain will be, and that if during sued war any other should join against Japan Great will than take part in the war as me ally in Japan The war now going on is covered by the treaty. Great Britain is neutral, but it any Power should come Russia's assistance Great Britain must assist Japan. Thu treaty, as has just been said, represents the accepted policy. But it doss not constitute a policy, fur it is merely a fragment, dealing with special interests and specific eventuates. It provides certain means for facilitating the default Oi Japanese and of British interests in the Ear > East The eventualities which it contemplates, I however, are only a part oi those which may l happen j perhaps not the most immediately j probable part

In view of the recent victory of Japan, it might not be improbable that the Russia autocracy, id order to save itself Iron revolu­tion at home, would user atoll to tha utmost to obtain help from another Power. This contingency, not highly pro liable, is quite within the of pos­sibility, and for that event the Brit: h nation ought to be prepared, and the Government in particular ought to be every respect ready. Readiness means having decided beforehand on the necessary plans of campaign, including all arrangements and the faros to be used, and not having when the time cines to sit dews and deliberate if anything is to be done, and if | so what it is to be. div.head:
THE WAR
ANOTHER JAPANESE ADVANCE
LINDEVITCH TO PURSUE FABIAN TACTICS

div.p: General Lindevitch is taking measures to cope with the Japanese turning movement.(Havas)
The Japanese are again advancing. They caused the Russian reargaurd to retreat 13 miles to xxx, which is 40 miles to the south of Gutzuling.(Reuter)

It is uderstood that the intention to mobilize on a large scale has been abndoned for the present. Only drafts of sufficient strength to stiffen Linievitch's army will be sent. Te General will pursue Fabian tactics. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE JAPANESE LOAN
SCENES IN LONDON

div.p: The bankers state they are receiving many French subscriptions for the American version of the Japanese loan.(Reuter)

The exterior of the bamks which are issuing the Japanese loan resembles Boxing Day at the theatres. Special police are preserving order. There are long queues of persons outside the banks, the largest being around the Hong Kong and Shanghai office. It is certain that the loan will be heavily oversubscribed.(R)

The "Daily Telegraph", in taking up the idea of strengthening the alliance between Britain and Japan, says that the suggetion is receiving general approbation in the City. This will especially be the case if the idea enjoys the moral support of America.(Reuter)

A systematic constitutional agitation has begun in Finland and is spreading considerably. A demonstration at Abo was attended by 20,000 persons. Crowds are parading the streets waving revolutionary flags; bands are playing national airs.(Reuter)
H.M. cruiser "Lancaster" has arrived here.(Reuter)
Five Cardinals have sent M.Loubet a protest in favor of the Concordat.(Havas)
The Cabinet has been formed with Signor xxxx as President and Signor Tittoni as minister for Foreign Affairs.(Havas)

div.head:
THE TROUBLES OF RUSSIA
THE CRIMEAN DISTURBANCES
VIOLEN OUTBREAKS IN CAUCASUS

div.p: The disturbances begn here on Sunday evening when the town was ignited in five places. The crowd obstructed the work of extinguishing the themes. All the police stations were wrecked and the prisoners liberated the attempt to sack the municipal treasury wa frustrated. (Reuter)

Violent outbreaks are occuring in many parts of the Caucasus both in the town and country. The peasants declare that they can only obtain concessions by force, and they are, therefore, attacking the municipal buildings and the country seats of the nobles. The Government is sending troops into the district. There is a marked recrudescence of unrest throughout Russia, apparently in pursuance of a "mot d'ordre." (Reuter)
Warships and military reinforcements have arrived here. Order has been restored(R)

div.head: A.L.M. & D.S.-
div.p: At the Sailors and Soldiers' Institute last night, a lecture was given under the auspices of the above society b the Rev. Reginald Rynd, BA, on the "The Natural Use of the Voice". A ggrsat deal of valuable information was conveyed by the lecturer as to the proper mode of developing the vocal organs, and his description of the various reasonant organs of the human frame- in themselves very lucidly described-was rendered still more plain by a large diagram of the head and throat, The importance of the proper management of the resonant organs, nd the way in whic to best avoid the hindrances to good singing, presented by the tongue, throatiness, etc., were fully set forth, and at the close of the lecture the appreciation of the audiece as plainly expressed. A vote of thanks to the reverend lectuer was proposed by Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, KCMG, who presided, and was heartily accorded. We hope that Mr.Rynd wll favor he society with many more of these interesting contributons to the proper understanding of music, nothwithstanding the discouragingly small number of members who turned up last night.

div.head:
TERRIBLE ACCIDENT
THREE MEN BURIED ALIVE
div.p: A terrible accident occurred at Alexandria yesterday afternoon about 5 o'clock, by which three men lost their lives. In Stamboul street, just behind Groppi's establishment, building operations are proceeding, and at the time mentioned the foundations of the house being built gave way, burying three native masons in the debris. Towards evening, the dead bodies of two of the men were recovered, while the other remained buried under a mass of earth and stone. From investigations which we have made, it appears that at a depth of four metres these men were engaged in building up the earth i nthe form of an arch. Th carelessness of native workmen is notorious. It seems that in forming the arch they had taken away some earth on the side of the escarpment. This weakened the layer of earth on top and caused the landslip. Under the circumstances the blame for the unfortunate accident must fall on the victims themselves, as no one but they can tell the stability of their position. Had they been simple workmen, the responsibility would lie with the employers, who should have capable overseers.

div.head: AL AZHAR UNIVERSITY
div.p: The third uhma of the Al Ahzar University, Sheikh Ahmed el Hanbali, has resigned his seat in the council of directors of the University. Two sheikhs only remain, Sheikh Hassanein El Boulaki and Sheikh Hassanein El Edoui. We hear on good authority that candidates for cadi hip will near future, after passing an examination at Al Azhar at an early period of their studies there, go through a special course of training which will be entirely independent of the ancient university

div.head: UPPER EGYPT HOTELS COMPANY
div.p: Referring to the announcement which appeared in our columns yesterday, we are informed that the Savoy Hotel, Assouan, will not now be included in the above company, as stated, owing to the fact that the necessary arrangements have not been concluded with the Anglo-American Company. The capital of the new company is 220,000, in shares of 4 each, snd 100,000 in 5% first mortgage debentures. The directors will be Mr. AE Harrison, general manager of Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son, (Egypt), Ltd, George Nungovich Bey, Mr. Charles Baehler, and Mr. Pagnon.

div.head: STATE OPERA
div.p: We hear that a petition is circulating among the abonnes of the Khedival Opera House (and obtaining numerous signatures), copies of which will be addressed to the Minister of Public Works and to Lord Cromer, Mr Vincent Corbett and Sir William Gastin. The petitiondeals with the decision of the Socitete Artistique to bring an Italian company over in the season 1905-1906, in spite of the decision taken some time ago, and aproved by the Government, to bring French companies over in alternate years. The signatories of the petition complain of this breach of the regulations pointing out that the arrangement previously made enabled good new operas (which by the concession must be produced to the number of four a year) to be brought before the Cairo public. They disclaim all nationalist bias and assert that the plea of the societe Artistique, viz, that a good French company cannot be procured, is utterly untenable. They therefore beg the Minister of Public Works to intervene on behalf of the Government and the public. In our opinion the best way out of the difficulty would be to revoke the concession as soon as possible, and hand over the entire business to a good impressario.. The proverb "Too many cooks" is alarmingly true in Egypt.

div.head: CAIRO ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS
div.p: Many additions have been made to the menagerie in these gsrdens during the last two months, and one of the prettiest sights now to be seen near Cairo is that of the young gazelles and ibex, of which more than a dozen have recently been born at Ghizeh, playing and frisking about with their mothers in the large paddock which occupies the site of the ruins of the old palace. The births thi spring also include an Arui wild sheep and two Hedjaz sheep, and among the birds, besides numerosu doves of various kinds, two buff-backed egrets have been hatched and reared. Seventeen animals have been presented: an Egyptian weasel by Mrs. Colville, a hawk-eagle by Mr. H. Raczinski of Alexandria, a Nilotic waran-lizard from Luxor by Prof. Dr. G. Schweinfurth, a ring-necked parakeet by Mrs.Bazil, three slender lorises by Mr. J.A. Tarrell, a jungle cat by Mr.AE Branch, seven trumpeter bullfinches and a spotted cuckoo by Mr. GH Malcolm, an a greyheaded love-bird by Mr. S. Hanauer. The purchases during the same period include a yellow baboon, avery larg bonnet-monkey, a white nosed red monkey, some lemurs, two species of wild cat, a Loder's gazelle from the Fayoum, a mouse deer from India, several pretty species of birds not previously represented in the collection, as the lavender finch of Tropical Africa and the Pein nightingale, also two Mina birds, and finally an Algerian tortoise.
By the kind permission of the Inspector General of Prisons, the band of the Ghieh Boys' School will play on Friday afternoons in the gardens throughout this year.

div.head:
THE SIRDAR AT SUAKIN
RECEPTOON BY INHABITANTS
div.p: During his recent visit to Suakin, the Sirdar distributed several robes and other valuable gifts, such as medal dresses, watches, revolvers, knives, and shaving articles, to a large number of sheikhs of tribes, clergy, and faithful guides and attenants for their loyal services these few years to the Government. After this ceremony was over he delivered an eloquent address in English which lasted 45 minutes, and which was then interpreted into Arabic by his Arabic secretar, Shaheen Bey, and afterwards again interpreted into Hadendow by the Commandant of Police, Mohamed Bey Ahmed.

In the evening his Excellency was entertained at dinner at the Moudirieh. Afterwards a reception was held, when Saghcolaghassi Aly Effendy Ahmed,Deputy-Inspector of Suakin Moudirieh, addressed his excellency the Sirdar in English as follows: "Your Excellency,-I have been chosen by the Egyptian officers, officials and employes of the Government of Suakin to stand respectfully before your Excellency and to express their happiness on your visit to this province and town. All the people of whatever station, the richest and the poorest, the highest and the lowest, have taken this oppurtunity to welcome you by their shouts and respond to the consideration and goodwill you have ever shown to all. All whom you find around you are anxious to assure you of their warm feelings and pleasure. The whole Sudan recognises and is grateful for the wise and good administration of the coutnry. The whole Sudan recognises and is ggrateful for the manner in which the happiness and well-being of all classes are considered. Not only the whole Sudan, but the whole world recognises the spledid way in which the country has thriven during the years which you have been Sirdar and Governor General of the Sudan, and wonders at the magnificent manner in which the resources of the coutnry are being developed. It is true that during this period all departments of the GOvernment have accomplished much, but in this province we watch perhaps more keenly than others, the miles of railway which are joining the Nile and Red Sea, and the plans for the development of the ports of the Sudan. We know that all that has been the result of your master spirit and encouragement. I am not able to express all that is on my mind, but specially we would thank your Excellency for the honor of your visit to us this evening, and in this way showing that you have a warm heart and kind feelings for all those serving the Government of this country. I ask all who are present to drink the health of his Excellency the Sirdar of the Egyptian Army and the Governor-General of the Sudan, El Ferik Sir Francis Reginald Wingate Pasha." The following congratulatory order was published after the Sirdar's departure:-El Miralai Howard Bey, Mr. Kerr, and the military officers and officials of the Egyptian Army and Sudan Government for their admirable arrangements for his recetion, and for their good and hard work to which the very marked improvement in the condition and progress of the town and province since his last inspection in 1901 is due. "He was much struck with the smartness and turn out of the guard of honor furnished by the 3rd Battalion, and the excelence of the organisation and the careful arrangements made for the treatment of the sick in the military and civil hospitals. The interest taken in education as evinced by the satisfactory state of the school and scholars, was most marked. He also wishes you to convey to El Miralai Macauley Bey his great appreciation of the hard and valuable work done by him and his staff on the new Railway, of which the substantial progress already made is the best testimony. In conclusion he would like to express to you, your officers and officials, and to all classes of people of Suakin, his cordial thanks for the loyal and hearty reception on his arrival and hospitatlity extended to him during his stay." (Signed): LO Stack, Kaimakam, Mil. and Private Secretary.

div.head:
CANON DAVIS MEMORIAL
DEDICATION SERVICE
div.p: The short service held by the Bishop in Jerusalem and the East at 4:45pm on Monday in St. Mark's Church was quite private. It had not been possible to fix the exact hour until the day before, too late t announce it in the "Gazette". The Bishop, who was attended by his acting chaplain, the Rev. Canon Ward, inserted the following special prayers in a shortened form of evening service. "In the faith of Jesus Christ we dedicate this memorial stone, now handed over to the charge of the chaplain and the trustees of St. Marks Church, to the peretual memory of the Csnon Edwin John Davis, MA i nthe church in which he s long ministered. May those who worship here, and face his effigy as they go out from this House of God into the world, hear in memory the example of one of whose loving and charitable labours for the good of Christ's poor, should stimulate the spirit of charity in others; and whose watchful care of the interests of this foundation of St. Mark's has left to his successors great possibilities for happy influence in the chaplaincy which he served for so long a time. "Assist us mercifully, O Lord, in these our supplications and prayers, and in this our act of thy servants towards the attainment of everlasting salvation, that among all the changes and chances of this mortal life we may ever be defended by Thy most gracious and ready help; through Jesus Christ our Lord. Amen"

div.head: LA DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Delegation Municipale s'est reunie le 28 mars 1905 a 4h. pm sous la presidence de M. Amb. A. Ralli. La Delegation arrete parmi le programme des routes a faire cette annee. Les devis at cahier des charges devront etre presentes au fur et a mesure au College pour la mise en adjucation. Elle adjuge a M. Degiarde la furniture de 60 bancs et 40 chaises pour le jardin Nousha; la route de Ramleh, a M Erriques; enfin la fourniture de balais et couffins, a MM Abdel Rahim Hekel et a M Stamatepoulo. Les offres presentes pour la demolition d'une maison, rue Sinadino, n'ayant pas para satisfaisantes, la Delegation decide de refaire une nouvelle adjucation pour ce travail. La Delegation renvoie au sujet de la construction de la conduite de raccordement pour le deversement des eaux de lavage des nouveaux filtres. Elle proposera a la Commission l'overture d'un credit supplementaire de LE 600 pour le jardin Nouzhe. La seance est le ee a 8h. pm.

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
div.p: THEATRE ZIZINIA
NOTRE JEUNESSE

Avec la representation de Notre Jeunesse, la compagnie Coquelin Cadet a pu enregistrar une de see crations, et M. Jean Coquelin s'y est autant distingue dans le role de Lucien Briant qu'avanthier dans celui du marquis de La Seigliere Quant a Mme Moreno, elle a su rendre a la perfection deux ou trois soenes pathetiques qui lui ont valune ovation. Nous devons encore une mention particuliere a Mme Bouchetal et a l'heureuse interprete du role de Luoienne Briant qui ont ete toutes deux justement remarquees. M. Coquelin Cadet a termine la representation par trois monologues qu'il a debite d'uue facon exquise. Ce soir Lee Romanesques, comedie en trois actes de M. Edmond Rostand, et L'Ete de la Sanit Martin, comedie en un acte de MM. Meilhac et Halevy.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Major General Sir Ronald Lane and Lieutenant General Sir Thomas Kelly Kenny, who have respectively held the positions of Military Secretary and Adjucant General to the British Army, are leaving Egypt on Monday next by the Bibby SS Staffordshire from Port Said Sir Ronald Line is staying with Mr. Gould until tomorrow when he returns for a few days to Cairo.
Yesterday Sir Ronald paid a visit to Victoria College in company with Mr. Gould and was very much pleased with this institution.

The "Journal du Cairo" remarks:- On donne comme probable la nomination de M. Sheldon Amos, juge au Tribunal indigene de re instance du Caire, comme conseiller a la Cour d'appel indigene en remplacement de M. Coghlan.
The Italian man of war "Liguria" is expected to arrive at Alexandria shortly with the Duke of the Abruzzi, who is on his way home after a voyage round the world.

It is not generally known that the credit for the suggestion of England's purchase of the "St. James Gazette", whose 75th birthday is to be celebrated by a banquet in London. When an oppurtunity offered of buying the Suez Canal shares which now form so important a national asset, it was Mr. Greenwood who suggested the purchase to Disareli. Disareli jumped at it, and the thing was done. The statesman got the kudos, but to the journalist belongs the credit.

Egypt has been from the beginning the background for a career of much distinction in the case of Captain Colin Keppel, who has been recently appointed to succeed Sir A Milne in command of His Majesty's yachts. During the attempt to relieve General Gordon, in the subsequent rescue of Sir C. Wilson under Lord Charles Beresford, on the Nile in 1898, when he commanded the flotilla, and at the CB, Captain Keppel won unqualified praise for his ability and courage. As a midshipman be participated in the bombbardment of Alexandria.
Mr JIR Dempster, whose sudden death we annonced yesterday, was chief engineer of the New Egyptian Compsnys Nile reclamation works.
Mr.ALP Weigall has been appointed inspector to the Antiques Service at an annual salary of LE 400.
The Rev. Alf. A. Cooper, MA, of the British and Foreign Bible Society, is expected back in Alexandria on the 1st prox. Mr. Cooper travels by way of Berlin, Vienna, and Constantinople.

The following officers have been granted leave of absence on private affairs:- Capt. S.J.Somerville and 2nd Lieut.CEG Varnon, 2nd Royal Inniskiling Fusiliers; Liet Col. Berks. Regt., Capt.GB Byrne and 2nd Lieut RSW Walpole, 2nd Rifle Brigade; Liet. TC Cunningham, AOD. Major EJ Lawson, AVD.

div.p: D'après les nombre usas plaintes qui nous ont parvenue» eu ce» derniers temps, il sem bleuit que las belles traditions créées par Ch* tawajr Bey lors do son séjour 4 la Douane comme Directeur local, ne Loi survivront guère.

Le ooâmerce,oa général, commeuoe 4 regret ter bien «noèrament «lui qui occupe actuelle Otent le» haute» fonctions municipales que l'on tait .Depuis quoique temps, on effet, la Dirac tien locale sembla sa oem plaire à la recherche d'innombrahîee tracasseries qui finiront, peu 4 peu, pu détraquer cette merveilleuse machine que Cbaleway Bey avait «u si habilement mettre au point Cette constatation est très re­grettable 4 ton» les point» do vue; car, en per- révérant dans la voie qu'elle tend 4 adopter, la nouvelle Diroctiou locale ne pourra que porter un assex grave préjudice tant au bon fonction Bernent du service douanier qu'4 toutes les branche* du Commerce de oo paya C'est donc presque l'opposé de ce que l'on avait espéré et de tels principes sont aussi contraires aux inté­rêts du Trésor égyptien qu'à ceux des particu­lier» eux-mêmes.
Nom bous contenterons peur aujourd'hui de signaler le bit 4 l'attention de qui de droit; mai» « ht néôenité nous y oblige, noua expose rwt» en détail las griefr du Commerce.
L'industrie Sucriare en Egypte

L'industrie saorière introduite en Egypta par IirasïlPsohan* cessa d'y prospérer jusqu'au jour ob k sultan de la betterave prit en Europe l'extension que l'on sait, gièce à L'inau­guration du système de» prime».

Mais tandis que les diverse» nations euro­péen ne», ponr favoriser Leur exportation, riva­lisaient dans l'attribution de primes de pins en plu forte*, les Etats-Unis imposaient le* sucre» importés dan» k proportion oh ils avaient été favorisée ; ce qui amena k convocation d'an Congrès à Bruxelles où le principe des primes fut aboli.'Seule k Russie a refuré d'adhérer aux alarmes de cette fameuse convention desti­née 4 marquer us data mémorable dans 1m annales de l'industrie sucrière.

Le stwre de betterave, qui était tombée arti- $oi«il«Mat 4 de très bu pii* ne pourra pree- que pins être exporté 4 causa de le concumna du sucre de oann* qui reprendra sa place pré pondérante dan» le marché mondial

Une surproduction cependant n'oit pas i craindre l'parue que la production H trouvera nécessairement limitée par la manqua d'ex per ration, par la suppression due primo» do labri- cation et par la réduction de la culture do lu otittorave, 2* parce qu'il y a tandem» dam certain» paya peur venir en aide 4 l'agriculture et à Tiadootne, d'augmenter la waauinmaUon A l'intérieur par la rédaction de» droit*. CW ainsi qu'en franco M. Bouvier, prévoyant le a la f'rauce qui exportait jusque-là 670 mille tonnes de sucre par an, réduisit en septembre
l'impôt sur la fabrication du ancre de Ir. 64 à fc. 25 par quintaL
Ce dégrèvement a eu pour résultat de faire passer la oousununatiou pendant 1 exercice 1993-

de 455.762 tonnes à 613.944 tonnas. La diminution de 37 œntunes par Kg, dans l'impôi a donc produit uae augmentation dans la con­sommation locale de 158.182 tonnes en une seule année, soit 33, ? %. fendant oes huit dernières années la consommation a anoore augmenté de 34 % sur la période correspon­dante de L'année dernière, il. Bouvier pont à juste titre être fier de cette mesure,qui pouvait paraître téméraire au début, mais qui est aujourd'hui couronné du plus brillant suocès. Maintenant que l'expérience est faite, il est à souhaiter que les autres pays suivent l'exemple de La Ÿrance.

Le relèvement doa prix du sucre permettra en outre da remettre en état les a ombreuses ueines des Antilles qui étaient tombées en ruine oes dernières années ; elles ne pourront peut-être plus compter sur le marché européen, yùle sacre de betterave sera consommé sur place, mais elles 'suffiront à peine à pourvoir à la consommation américaine qui est, comme on le sait, formidable.

L'Angleterre et l'Orient resteront des mar­primes L'Egypte aura gagné non seulement des débouchés extérieure nouveaux mais encore reconquis son propre marché, qui ne consom­mait- plus que les sucres dite de Trieste.

L'industrie du pays restera donc maltresse 'du marebé malgré la hausse des prix qui sers eu temps normal de '10 ir. par 10U Kg. sur les marchés antérieure. La Société doa Sucreries et Raffinerie d'Egypte qui a pu traverser le» crises terribles où tant d'autres entreprises similaires ont sombré,et qui depuis l'achat dus sucreries de la Daïra tiauieb, représente 4 elle proctiré k Uonvenûun do Bruxelles 4 l'indus- triu auarière.

U est partant difficilede s'expliquer comment alors que le sucre hausse do prix (50,60 %) et que le» affaires augmentent, lés actions de k société de* sucrera.-» sent en baisse. Nous sa­vons qu'en Europe l'industrie sucrière tra-

w une crise aiguë dans la période actuelle transition et après une recolle exception- bellement mauvaise, Mais eu Egypte où k Convention a assuré an brillant avenir anx sacres et où Je mouqae de plaie et les variations atmosphériques né sont pas 4 crain­dre ponr les récolte», grâce 4 l'eau du Nil, non» ne Comprenons paa on vérité pourquoi le» valeurs sucrières locales doivent suivra dans leu» fluctuations les valeurs sucrières étran­gères qui sont en général très dépréciées sur tous les Tnirchés européen* depuis le nouvel eut de choses.

il y a bien un rapport entra les deux, Ainsi de valeur, mais il ait d'un effet opposégenres l'industrie égyptienne bénéficiera de tous les désavantages que la nouvelle convention a créé* pour l'industrie européenne. la ruine et le» perte» de celle-ci se traduiront ponr celle-là en.bénéfice ut en prospérité.

L'examen même artificiel da k question des sueras aurait suffit pour édifier la premier venu. Mais eu Bourse on ne raisonne guère on vous répondra que Le» Calculateurs avec leurs études et leu» paperasse» y perdent perdent générale- meut leur fortune. Voilà pourquoi daus la Bourse d'Alexandrie comme dans celle da Paris les cours montent et descendent en dépit du bon sens. Les préjugé», tihumenr et l'état d'esprit de quelques-uns sufEàeut pour donner souvent le ton au marché. Un n'est jamais plus moutonnier qu'en Bourse.

Ajoutons 4 propos de cotte Société que le» importation» de sucre brut; effectué» pour wn compta sent exfionérés actuellement de tou* l'enouuragornent de k culture de la caune à suera, le (iouversement a déd ié de réduire dons de fortes proportions les droits de fabri­cation payés jusqu'ici. Les énormes quan­tités de sucre importés par la Société por­tés sur Je» statistiques douanières de l'année dernière doivent lui avoir procuré aux prix actuel* un béuéfico net de £ 400.009 sur les prix d'achat, du plus le stock de suore entre les mains do la Société doit être considérable et le déficit dans la consommation moudisie est évalué 4 plus da 1 million de tonne». Les résultat» financiers de l'exerdoe en cour», qui prendra fiu au 31 Octobre, seront donc sous précédents. Le» prix moyens du sucre sur le marché d'Alexandrie étaient pour lespafns de P.T. 56 lé catitar en 1992-1903, P.T. 61 en 1903-1904 et P.T. 90 en 1904-1905, Les prix uut augmenté dans lus même» proportions pour le sucra on tablettes, cou cassé, pilé, mais un peu moins pour le granulé.

La différence des prix entre k campagne 1992 03 et celle de 1994-05 accuse nue aug mentation de près de 70%, en faveur de l'exercice actuel. De plus ta production égyp­tienne $ui était on 199203 de «6.509 sac* u dû atteindre environ TUQ.IWO sacs l'année der- mère, chiffra qui aéra nécessairement dépassé cette anute ci.
Cette augmentation considérable doproduc- tiou a penui» d'abaisser le» frai» de fabrication à un chiffre qu'on n'aurait osé espérer.

Pour l'exercice 1902 03, k Société des Sucreries et Uaffiut-rie a distribué un divi­dende de 10 % aux actionnaires; on peut donc s'attendra pour l'exercice actuel qui bénéficie d'une plus-value do 70 %, sur la vente d'une production double comme quantité, à un divi­dende beaucoup plus fort.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: MOUNTED INFANTRY SPORTS AT WADY NATROUN.

The M.L., under Major Pine-Coffin, D.S. O, old most successful sports on the 24th at the Oasis of Wady Natroun,, wbere they at present bolding their quarterly encampment. The ground was very kindly lent, and every assistant given by Mr. Bensilum, the hospitable manager of the Salt and Soda company. The ground presented at most picturesque appearance, as nearly all the Bedouins from the surroundings desert attended dressed in their beet gala costumes, and all armed with long tint-lock guns, pistols, etc. Several of them brought their families, or which a harem .lent was erected. The ladies cooked very picturesque and seemed to thoroughly enjoy themselves. Quito a novel sight was afforded by the monks from the neighboring Coptic monasteries, who turned up in great force. Their sombre costume and black turbans aflorded a striking contrast to the other spectators. The tug of war between the three Motions -raw one of the most popular items. The final pull between the Brigade Motion and the 2nd Royal Berks was a magnificent one, and lasted about 12 minutes, resulting in a win tor the Berks. "The 'picketing out race" was won 'easily by the luniakiiling Fusilier section, who completed their task in the short time of 12 minutes. The last race on the program was a "bun and treacle race," which seemed far more pleasant to watch than to take part in. The prizes were distributed at the end of the sports by Mins Dolly Pine-Coffin. Amongst those present we noticed Major Pine-Coffin, D.S.O., Mrs. Pine-Coffin and Master Miss Pine-Coffin, Mrs. Lewellin, Capt. Nuuu, D.S.0., Ghumous Sarabamon, Bishop of Khartoum, Capt, R.C Wilson, Amba Joabbis, Archbishop of GcJdgam, Lieut. Uruabie, Mabrook Zamuut, Jmdeh of Gawabees tribe, Lieuu Hump, higuor Botany and Mias Barany, humous ibiuiuui, bishop of Din Sorriau, Lieut. Lloyd, Miss Rose, Ghumous Maximus, bishop ol Abiuuwkir,'Mr. Beuailum, Ghumous Ayoub, Bishop of Din Amhabtahome, Ghumous MichieJ, Bishop of Din Baramous. At the end of the sports the Coptic Bishop of Khartoum mode a speech in classical Arabic, a translation of which is given below, A suitable reply was made by Msj. Fine-Coffin. The follow iug is a lint of the events and result:
Picketing out race (16 men and 1 Sargt.) —1st, luniakiiling Fusiliers 2nd, 2nd Royal Berks.

3.—Walking Match (150 yds).—lsr, Pta Ewart; 2nd, Pta. Anderson; 3rd, Pta Raymond:3rd Pta. Garrett. 4.—3 legged Race.—lst, Pta Ewart McCreanor ; 2nd, Ptos. Allan and McShaae j 3rd, Ftes, Gallagher and Percy. ' 5.—Native Girls' Race (carrying buckets of water on head).—1st, Sarifa Said •, 2nd, Mabrook Abdalla. Б..Tug of war (Saises v. Wadi Natroons). —1st, Wadi Natroons. 7.—Bedouins' Race (350 yds.).—1st, Ibrahim Fadalla; 2nd, Mahomed Denrish; 3rd, Abdulla Mahomed. g.—Tug of war (Final). — 2nd Royal Berks. 9—Donkey Race (Sergeants)-—1st, Sgt. Chambers; 2nd, Sgt. Noble. 10 —Officers Donkey Race—1st, Maj. Pine Coffin ; 2nd, Lt- Crosbie ; 3rd,Copt.Wilson. 11.— Bun and Treacle Race, — 1st, Azac Farak; 2nd, Mabrook. 'The following is a translation of the Bishop of Khartoum's speech: Ladies and Gentlemen,—We are very pleased on this great day to have amongst us the commandant of the British troops, and from the bottom of our hearts we wish him welcome. His presence lighted the Wadi, and aaa the inhabitants of the place as well as the priests bf the monasteries are much plesed with his visit. Before the arrival of the commandant and the troops the sun had disappeared here and now ho appears again. All the people hare and the manager of the Wady estate am very much honored by his visit to us end I cannot find any words to express the contentment of the priests on the occasion. We are praying God to protect H.M. Edward VII, King of England, H.H. Abbas II, our Khedive, our H. the Patriarch and his colleague, Father Samerion. It is by the request of all the people of the Wady Natroum that I pronounce these few words, which I am happy to say come from the bottom of my heart. I wish yon all, ladies and gentlemen, prosperity and long life. FOOTBALL. McKEBVOR SHIELD. The above teams met on the 23rd inst. at Abbearich to decide who should hold the above trophy, kindly presented by the Hon. Mr. McKeevor. Loth teams received a great ovation on entering the arena. At the appointed rime (or starting the referee, Mr. R McAllister, D.C.M., lined his men out in the following order: F. Company 1st, goal, Fortin; backs, Peggs and Page: half-backs,Calvin, Collion: , and Edwards; forwards, Smyth, Harbinson, Duffy, Galbraith, and Linton. P. Company 2nd, goal, McCallion; backs, Cohee and Reilley ; half-back, Elliot, Templeton, and McTeague; forwards, Reford, Magee, Mullan, Paton, and Judson Captain Magee guested correctly the spin of the coin and decided to defend the roadside goal. About 800 would be pretest when Smyth started the ball scrolling. Edward the first to get away and sent well into goal, but McCallion saved well. On the kick-off Mullan got away and passing out to his right Refold got possession and sent in a grasshopper to Parris, who in saving conceded a corner. This was well taken by Buford, and Magee getting the leather at his toe had no difficulty in scoring first blood for the seconds, the custodian not having an earthly chance to save. On, resuming Harbinson got on a good run and passing out to Smyth, who was given offside, this relieved matters for a while The second pressed for a while and Reford from a nice centre by Magee made the seconds 2 to nil amidst deafening cheers. Shortly after this Judaea had a good chance to score, but his shot went on the wrong side. The excitement was now intense as Paton, with a beauty, recorded the third goal. Collins, Smyth, and Harbinson now turned the tide by making tracks for McCallion, but the latter, along with Cohee and Reilley, was all O. K. The right wing of the seconds was now doing some grand work and gave Partis plenty to do, the latter being ably supported by Peggs and Page. Shortly after halftime was announced, the following being the score:— F Company. 2nd …………3 Goals F Company 1st... ... ..........Nil Alter the usual refreshments both teams entered the arena once more, The first thing noticeable was a good run by Beford, who after dodging a couple of opponents sent well in to Partis, who saved finely. Play was now carried towards midfield, but Smyth could not get away and Templeton got away on his own and shot strongly into goal, Partis felling in the attempt to save. Everything now rated in favor of the seconds, who added a filth goal per Mulian. There was only one team in the game so for as one can readily guess. The first eleven now woke up, but Smyth, when in a good position to score, was given offside. This, however, did not keep them away, and McCallion got plenty to do, which he did in a masterly fashion. However, he had to bow down to Peggs, who scored the first goal for the first eleven amidst cheers. This helped to pat the seconds on their mettle and Beford grazed the crossbar. Shortly after the crossbar fell from a great shot from Paton. Darkness was now setting in. Still the spectators urged their favorites to go in and win; Fall rime was now approaching, as Page handled the ball The free, however, proved unproductive, Duffy clearing. The referee was very strict in his decisions. Mullan, Magee and Reford were now combining well and Page could not master the right wing, who wore a terror to the defense. Play was in midfield when the whistle sounded full time. The fioal score was: F Company 2nd R. L... ... ... 5 Goals F, Company 1stR.L,,. ... ... 1 Goal Mr.P.McAlliater refereed to the satisfaction of all concerned.

div.head: GROSS CRUELTY TO BIRDS.
div.p: To toe Editor the Egyptian Gazette. Sir,—I wish to bring before the notice of your readers a moot distressing case witnessed by a party of four from this house on Sunday, the 26th inst, when returning from the Barrage on No. 1 of the Tramways Co.'s. Steamboats. A native had caught about 40 young sparrows and tied them by the legs to a piece of string about 2 feet long- To get the birds within this limit they were packed all-round the string, only the heads arid breasts appearing, thus looking like a solid column of quivering life. The string was tied so tightly that in some cases the birds in struggling had severed their legs, others, more timid, had died. Over this mass of life and death a crowd was gloating and bargaining for the birds, themselves should one be too weak to move, it was thrown out to drown. We obtained the lot, and liberated them. About two-thirds reached the banks, some minus a leg, and the rest had either died, or were too weak to sustain their flight and fell into the water. Should such a thing be tolerated 1 We are, I think, getting beyond the barbaric age, and I, for my part, will do my best to prevent a recurrence of such a ghastly sight, if it wore only for the mute appeal of the birds themselves, and not considering the "ascendancy" of man, which is only too obvious in this case. I do not know whether a law exists relating to this, as If 1 had been acquainted with it, the offenders would have been treated differently. — 1 am, eta Leonard H, Dolman. Maison Spiro, Sharia Knar-el-Nil, March 27.

div.head: "A QUEER GRAMMAR."
div.p: To the Editor or the "Egyptian Gazette." Sir,—If "Grammarian" had written a polite letter in reply to my review of Dirr's Colloquial Arabic Grammar I would take the trouble to prove to him that I was right in every instance, but filling his letter with abuses and sneers as he has done, I have no alternative but to lay it down with & smile upon my lips. I may, however, inform him that he is wrong also in supposing that I am foreign to the Arabic: tongue.—yours very truly,The Whites of tub Review, Alexandria, March 27.

VADE MECUM FOR THE HOMEWARD BOUND
MONDAY, MARCH 13, 1905.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt are Sicily and Southern Spain. Venice and the district (although they have many attractions) are not uniformly warm until much later. Florence is very beautiful and full of interest, but sometimes there are cold winds in the early spring.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe. They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

row.cell: Port Said or Alexandria to Brindisi
Port Said or Alexandria to Marseilles

div.p: The steamers, of the North German Lloyd, P & O., Orient and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 1/2 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg. The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay. These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: Southern Italy
div.p: The express goes north via Ancona, on the East coast, so that if you elect to go to Naples and Rome you may possibly have to wait at Brindisi some time for your train. At Brindisi there is nothing to see except the place which is supposed to have been the termination of the Appian way from Rome.
From Brindisi to Naples is a journey of 11 hours, but it can be broken at Taranto, two hours run from Brindisi.

Tarentum, founded in the 8th century B.C. by Spartans, was the first city of Great Greece. It has had a varied and exciting history, and remains of fine buildings - theatre, temple, circus and aqueduct - tell of its importance. Its situation is the most picturesque. The bay is the only secure port on the gulf, the entrance being so narrow that is it spanned by a bridge of a seven arches.

Salerno lies on the coast and is one of the most beautiful places in Southern Italy. On a height 905 feet above the sea stand the ruins of its Norman castle, giving a most imposing appearance to the place. The cathedral contains some very fine marble, and an 11th century Byzantine bronze door. Salerno was at one time a seat of learning, its medical school being famous ; the university was closed in 1817. You must visit Pastum's wonderful Greek temples, which are second only to those at Athens. The travertine walls, the gates, the Temples of Neptune and Ceres, and the Basilica are of surpassing interest and the place is a happy hunting ground for the sketcher.

Naples is reached in an hour and a half. Thence you must proceed to Rome, whence you may go by Florence and Bologna to Milan and the Italian Lakes; then by the St. Gothard line to Lucerne, Basle and Calais. Or ou may go by the coast, by Civita Vecchia and Pisu to Genoa and home by Turing and the Mont Cenis route.

div.head: ROUTE I. SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA.

From Messina the railway runs along the north coast of Sicily to Palermo and down the east coast to Syracuse via Taormina and Catania. TAORMINA is one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. The road goes winding up the hill in zig-zag fashion, and charming views - more beautiful the higher one gets - are unfolded to view. In and around the town is much to interest and visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restores under the Roamns. Catania is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, beyond that there is little of interest to the visitor. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless source of pleasure. The finest are at Syracuse and Girgenti on the south-west coast, and both places are well worth visiting. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was besieged by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain - his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. There is a fine theatre, alaso an amphitheatre and a temple to Diana, and the ruins of the great temple dedicated to the Olympian Jove. Girgenti stands on a hill 900 feet high and commands a magnificent view. The ancient ruins of Agrigentum are most interesting - of the timeple to juno there are still many columns stnading. There are also the remains of temples to Castor and Pollux, Theron, and the enormous pillars of the temple to Jupiter Olympus. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Guilia and and Royal Park are also worth a visit. Excursions from Palermo should be made to Monreale to see the beautiful Cloisters, and to Solunto, Cefalu, not forgetting also the Temples of Segesta and Selinunte. With its lovely scenery and delightful climate, its antiquities and beautiful vegetation, Sicily is certainly the most sttractive island in the Mediterranean.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay — Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [or you can drive] will take you on to Capri. This rocky little island is full of beautiful sea caves and grottoes, the exploring of which on a fine day, in a small boat, is a most fascinating occupation. The colour of the water is a perpetual joy, and the caves seem to be a veritable trap for sunshine. Of flowers and ferns there are plenty. Ischia and Procida can be visited in another little three or four days' trip from Naples. The steamers start from Immacolatella. The views of the coast, of Posilipo, Pozzuoli and Capo Miseno, are very fine. The little volcanic island of Procida is chiefly inhabited by sailors. The island of Ischia comes next, a charming resort, with mineral waters. The little harbour of Ischia, protected by its castle on a promontorv, is a volcanic crater. Casamieciola is the place at which you will stay, and from which you will make the ascent of Mount Epomeus for a glorious view.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but a few hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here. But a list of the principal attractions may not be out of place : - St. Peter's, the Vatican, Capitol and National Museums, Gallery of Modern Art, Villa Borghese, Doria, Colonna, and Lateran Palaces, Castle of St. Angelo, and the Pagan Antiquities, consisting of the Colosseum, Roman Forum, etc.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spen admiring the City of Flowers and its sur rounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with the Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes about an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

The run down to Pisa from Florence can be made two ways; either by Pistoja and Lucca or by Empoli. Lucea is one of the old fortified towns of Italy, with an imposing wall built round it, and massive gates leading into the town. Here is also the fine old Cathedral of St. Martino. In Pisa there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made, in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset. From Pisa there are good trains to Leghorn, where you can take boat to Genoa and thence to the Riviera or Milan and The Lakes.

div.head: ROUTE II. NORTHERN ITALY. Italian Lakes Italian & French Riviera
div.p: GENOA (La Superba). -The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest deathaverages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature —warm in winter and | deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and his-torical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.

Genoa is the principal port on the Mediter-­ranean, and the first commercial and shipping point of the Littoral, besides being the junction for the arrival and departure for all the principal cities of Europe, the Orient, and the United States, the Hamburg American, and North-German-Lloyd steamers from New York, and the Continent of Europe en route to China and Japan, stop at Genoa. The trains-de-luxe, and regular express trains from Paris and other large Continental cities make connections at Genoa en route to the Italian and French Rivieras, so that travellers to Rome, Naples, Alassio, San Remo, Nice. Mentone, Monte Carlo, etc., can arrange to spend a few davs in Genoa at one of its fine modern hotels. Genoa is built on steep hills rising abruptly from the Mediterranean, and the gorgeous panoramic views afforded from almost any terrace, street or building, must be seen to be appreciated Electric trams traverse every part, and tend to add the combination of the modern with all that is most ancient and in-teresting to the American tourist, who is doubly interested in seeing the birthplace of Christopher Columbus, the discoverer of America.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before: making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

VENICE is a 5 hour journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most, delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is un-like that of any other seaport. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.

From Venice you can go to Bologna via Padua; and then to Ravenna, one of the most ancient towns in Italy. Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour-and-a-half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San-Donino, and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

TYROL, INNSBRUCK, one of the finest and prettiest towns in the German Austrian Mountains, is 600 metres above sea level, and has many interesting features, both ancient and modern. It is admirably suited for spring and summer residence, and is a good centre for excursions in the summer months. There are three good railway services, via. Germany, Switzerland and Italy. Electric tramcars run constantly to many places of local interest. The Hotels are good, as also several Pensions, all being equipped with modern requirements. Full particulars and information can be obtained from any of Cook's offices.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.

COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza; also by tramway in two-and-a-half hours. The cathedral, entirely of marble, is one of the finest in N. Italy—1426-1526 a.d.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Caddenubbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellagio opposite. These four latter towns are in about the centre of the lake, and very close together, and the walk from. Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

Lake Maggiore is 37 miles long and varies in width from one-and-a-half miles to three miles, and though the banks are not generally so mountainous as those of the Lake of Como, the scenery is pretty and there are many in-teresting spots-at which to stay.

Pallanza, opposite the Borromean Isles, is well situated for a fine view over the Lake and the Alps. It is an interesting town and a good centre for making a tour round the Lake. Steamers are very frequent to all other towns up or down the Lake. Taking the steamer from Pallanza for Stresa, you call at Baveno, a pretty little spot where Queen Victoria stayed in 1879. Then you come to the most charming feature of this part of the Lake, the Borromean Islands. Isola Superiore is only a fishing hamlet, but Isola Bella is a picture. The castle was built in the 17th century and is worth visiting as well as the grounds. Stresa, the next stopping place by the steamer, is cooler and has a better air than places on the opposite side of the Lake, so that for the summer months it is a more preferable spot at which to stay.

div.head: Route III. Switzerland
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and granduers." The country has an area of only 15,720 square miles, and borders on France, Germany, Austria and Italy. It also has the proud distinction of being the source of three of Europe's biggest waterways - the rivers Rhine, Danube and Rhone. Mountains and lakes occupy almost the whole of Switzerland, there being practically no flat land or plains. The mountains or Alps are divided into three groups, the Pennine Alps, Helvetic Alps, and the Rhoetic Alps. The principal lakes are Constance, Geneva, Zurich, Lucerne and Neuchatel, then the lakes of Bienne, Thun, Brienz and Zug. The glaciers of Switzerland occupy about one-eighteenth of the space, and are about 400 in number, the principal of which is the Aletsch Glacier. There are also waterfalls of importance, such as the Rhine at Schaffhausen, the Aar at Handeck, Staubbach and Pletschbach at Lauterbrunnen, etc., etc.

Certain points are renowned for the view and may be selected as follows: - Col de la Faucille, near M. Reculets and M. Dole, above St. Cergue near Geneva, Chaumont above Neuchatel, Macolin above Bienne, the Hauen-steing above Olten, Albis between Zurich and Zug, Rigi between Zug and Lucerne, etc.

It depends very much on the point at which Switzerland is first entered which is to be the first stopping place; also whether the tour is on bicycle or foot, as naturally the cyclist wishes to be ever going from place to place and never turning back along the same road. But as centres for seeing the beauties and charms of each certain district the following may be helpful to visitors:- LAUSANNE as centre for Montreux, Vevey, Neuchatel, St. Maurice, Martigny, Aigle, Bex. etc. INTERLAKEN for the Bernese Oberland, Grindelwald, Murren, Lake Brienz, Thun, etc. CHUR for the Engadine, St. Mortiz, Davos Platz, Pontresina, Klosters, Ragatz, etc. ZURICH, Dolder, Schaffhausen.

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M, de Caprino and M. Generoso.

The Piazza Giardino, with its promenade and fountains, is close to the landing stage. A broad quay, the favorite promenade, extends the whole length of the town along the shores of the lake. In the Santa Maria degli Angiolo is a fresco of the Passion, the finest work of Bernardino Luini (1529). There are many interesting excursions to be made into the surrounding neighbourhood. MONTE GENEROSO, about 5,600 feet, is reached by taking steamer or train from Lugano to Capolago, then the mountain railway, which runs to the summit. The view is magnificent, being one of the finest in the Lombard Alps. Monte Salvatore is ascended by railway from Lugano Paradiso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bel-inzona in forty minutes. This pretty town situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna de Sasso, situated above the town is worth a visit, as it contains interst-ing paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and "The Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.

LUCERNE. - A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne is surrounded by walls with nine watch towers facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps. Seven bridges cross the Reuss, but the two old ones, the Kapell Brucke and Muhlen Brucke are of interest. Both have roofs, the former painted with scenes from the letter with a Dance of Death. The old water tower near the Kapell Brucke used to be a lighthouse or "Lucerna," giving its name to the town. In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous. Places of interest in the town are the Hof Kirche, dating from the 16th Century, the Lion of Lucerne Monument, near which is also an interesting garden, containing signs of glacier-worn rocks of a remote ice period. In the Bathaus is a Museum (War and Peace Museum) should also be visited.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgent stock and Sonnenberg, needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

The Rigi is a famous ridge between the Lakes Lucerne and Zug. The view is unsur-passed for extent and magnificence, including the view of 13 lakes, the Oberland, and many of the distant Alps. The sunset view is much finer than sunrise, and is best seen from the Roth-stock. Sunrise from Kulum.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of the lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axenstrasse.
SEELISBERG is on the opposite shore to Brunnen, and with the Sanitorium of Sonnen-berg forms one of the famous health resorts of the Lake of Lucerne

THE BURGENSTOCK may be reached in two ways; either by steamer from Lucerne to Kehrsiten, then the cable railway to the crest of Burgenstock; or the other way is to go to Stannstad by boat, and then drive up the fine new road. From Stannstad it is about 1 hour 40 minutes by electric railway to ENGLEBERG. The ascent of Titlis is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand, extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

ZURICH, capital of Canton Zurich, is beautifully situated in a mountain valley 1,300 ft above the sea. As a commercial tewn t is perhaps the most important in Switzer-land, having extensive manufactures in silk, cotton, and machinery. The old town is still picturesque, but is gradually being replaced by modern private dwellings and public buildings, amongst which is the Federal Polytechnic School and University. An interesting excur-sion is that to the Zurichberg 2,000 ft. above the sea, from which a fine sunset view can be obtained. Another favourite place is the Uttli-berg, about 6 miles south-west of Zurich.

div.head: Route III. - Contd.
div.p: THE ENGADINE - Coire. (Chur) is the best starting point for the Engatine, and from here carriages may may be had for all parts.
Thusis can be reached by rail in about an hour and a half, and here are the ruins of the oldest castle in Switzerland.
AROSA, six hours by diligence from Coire about 6,000 ft. aboce tho sea, magnificent scenery, and a favourite Alpine summer resort.
DAVOS. - Health resort with dry bracing air and much sinshine. In winter skating, tobogganing and snow shoeing are the amusements, in summer golf, and lovely local excursions are made.
KLOSTERS, situated in a broad valley amongst pastures and woods and surrounded by lofty mountains, is a much frequented sum-mer resort with several interesting mountain excursions.

ST. MORTIZ, 6,000 ft. above the sea, and the highest village in the Engadine consists of two parts St. Moritz Dorf and St. Moritz Bad. The latter is the summer resort during the months of May to September when golf, tennis, boating on the lake and Glacier excur-sions are the pastimes. St. Moritz Dorf during the winter season is frequented by lovers of winter sports such as skating, curling, tobogganing and ice sailing on the lake.
PONTRESINA. - Quite a popular summer resort, and much frequented by English visitors for its delightful excursions to several glaciers. St. Moritz Dorf is only an hour's walk through the forest.

THE BERNESE OBERLAND. - INTER-LAKEN is situated, as its name says, "between the lakes" the Lakes of Brienz and Thun; a fovourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Heheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees a chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Gressbach on Lake Brienz, Trummelbach and Staubbach in the Valley of Lauterbrunnen. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and views from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

Lauterbrunnen is only one hour by rail from Interlaken and here are the famous waterfalls of Staubbach (with a direct drop of 1,000 ft.) and Trummelback. From Lauterbrunnen to Murren is about an hour by electric railway.
MURREN is celebrated for the finest view of Alpine scenery to be had from any residential spot. The ascent of the Schilthorn can be made from here in about 4 hours.
Scheidegg is the starting place of the Jungfrau Railway, which ascends at present to a height of over 9,000 ft.

GRINDELWALD from Interlaken, about 1 hour 20 minutes, is a favourite centre for moun-tain excursions, and much frequented during sum-mer. It is sheltered by the Wetterhorn (12,000 ft.), Mettenberg (10,000 ft.) and Eiger (13,000 ft.), and between these three giants are two famous glaciers, the Ober and Unter Grindelwald, the Ober being the most popular.
ST. BEATENBERG, a charming place and favourite health resort, with fine lake and mountain scenery, 50 minutes from Interlaken by boat and funicular.
Brienz, at the north end of Lake Brienz, noted for wood carving, is worth a visit.

Other places which can be visited from Interlaken are Kandersteg (commanidng a magnificent panorama), Adelboden, Reichen-bach and Frutigen. Zermatt and the Rhone Valley can be reached from Kandersteg by way of the Gemmi Pass.

LAUSANNE itself is a mile-and-a-half from the shore of the lake up in the centre of the Jorat Hills. The port for landing from the steamer is Ouchy, roughly 30 miles from Geneva. The old and new parts of Lausanne are joined by a very fine bridge 135 yards long, called the Grand Pont, or sometimes Pont Pichard after the builder. The cathedral dates from the 13th century, and is a fine gothic edifice, the approach to the terrace of the cathedral is by 160 steps, or by a winding street, but the views are very fine from the terrace. Other interesting places are the cantonal museum, Musee Aarlaud, blind asylum, etc. Leaving Ouchy by steamer you come to Pully, Cully, then Vevey, famous as the scene of Rousseau's romance Nouvelle Heloise. Here also are important factories for tobacco, chocolate and infants food.

MONTREUX is composed of scattered villages partly on the hillside, partly on the late, and is divided into three parts, Le Chatelard, Les Planches, and Veytaux. Many excursions can be made from Montreux; to Vevey by electric tram, cable tram to Glion, having another fine view of the lake and surrounding mountains can be obtained, then to Naye, 6,500 feet, from where can be seen the Bernese Alps (Wetterhorn, Eiger, Jungfrau, etc.) Les Avants can be reached from Montreux by road, via Glion, and the fields of narcissus are a lovely sight in early summer.
Continuing on by rail, you pass Territet, Villeneuve, Aigle, Bex, St. Maurice, and the come to Martigny.

AIGLE, 20 minutes from Montreux is the starting point to the health resorts of Leysin, Diablerets, Chateau d'Oex (for its bracing mountain air cures); Villars (for milk cures, and lovely scenery); Chesieres and Bex (noted for its strong saline waters and grape cures). Near Bex is Les Plans for climatic cure, 3,600 ft., and a centre for mountain excursions.

Martigny is the starting place for the Tete Noir and Col-de-Balme routes to Chamonix, one of the most popular Alpine resorts, on account of being within easy reach of the famous Mer-de-Glace Clacier des Bossons. The ascent of Mont Blanc is made from here, and needs usually two days.

Champery, situated at the foot of the Dent-du-Midi, is reached by diligence from Monthey. From Martigny the railway goes to Brigue (the terminus of the Simplon and Furka routes) via Sion (starting point for Evolena, Arolla, Mayens, etc., and Viege (Visp) the junction of the line to ZERMATT. This last plce is a very important mountaineering centre, whence the ascent of Monte Rosa, the Matter-horn, Dome, Dent Blanche and the Breithorn can be made. The view of the snow-covered Alps and glaciers obtained from the railway to Gornergrat is really magnificent.

Eggshorn is a high mountain resort on the Brigue-Rhone Glacier road, whence the ascent of the Jungfrau is made quite easily. There are also numerous Glacier excursions, notably that to the Aletsch Glacier the largest in Switzerland.

div.head: Route IV. Greece and the Ionian Isles. Constantinople
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alex-andria; the climate in April is charming. Steamers run frequently both to Putras, and the Piraeus - which is the port for Athens. The advantage of disembarking at the latter place is that it is but five miles from Athens, which may be reached in twenty minutes by train; while the railway journey from Patras takes about 7 1/2 hours. The best steamers are those of the Khedival Mail Co. Greece is also very easily reached from either Smyrna or Constan-tinople; and there are frequent sailings by excellent steamers.

The first and most important sit to visit in ATHENS is, of course, the Acropolis - a rocky platform upon which were built some of the most famous buildings of classic times. Ascend-ing the great staircase, 70 ft. wide, and passing throuhg the Gateway built of marble from Pentelicus the Parthenon is reached - dedicated to Pa'las Athene by Pericles cir. 444 B.C., and adorned with priceless sculptures, many of which are now in the British Museum. There is the Erechtheion with its celebrated Caryatides; the Theseion and the beautiful little Temple of the Wingless Vistory. Close to the Acropolis lies Mars Hill, celebrated as the site where St. Paul preached to the Athenians, and where the Athenians held their public cCourt. On the Pnyx immediatley behind they assembled their meetings. On the south and south-east sides of the Acropolis are the beautiful columns of the Temple of Jupiter Olympus and the triumphal arch of Hadrian, the Temple of Aesculapius and the two ancient theatres - the Odeum, and the Theatre of Dionysus which is well preserved. These are but a few of the interesting buildings of ancient Athens.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara, for which a special train is run from Athens.

A charming trip can be made to Corinth by train (3 hours) through lovely scenery, and on to Mycenae, where can be seen the celebrated Tomb of Atreus and the Gate of Lions at the entrnce to Agamemmnons's Palace. From here it is quite possible to drive via Argos to Nauplia in the day. This is an interesting town, and the surrounding scenery is lovely. A pleasant afternoon's drive can be made to Tiryns with its Cyclopoean masonry, and to Argos with fine amphitheatre cut in the natural rock, and Acropolis 1,000 ft. above sea level. Epidaurus with its Temple of Aesculapius and very perfect amphitheatre is well worth the day's driving excursion. From Nauplia you can get to Olympia by rail via Pyrgos - the scenery is most picturesque. It is here that the celebrated Olympic games were help from B.C. 776 to A.D. 394 - the stadium is very perfect. The ruins of the Temple of Jupiter are quite splendid. The famous statue of Hermes is here. Patras is reached from Pyrgos by rail in ofur hours, from which port steamers to all parts of Europe run frequently. A charming trip can be made among the Ionian islands, Zanta, Cephalonia, etc. It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
You will get at Alexandria vessels belonging to different lines that will take you by various routes to Constantinople. The Khedivial stea-mers go by Piraeus for visiting Athens.
It is a great advantage to see Constantinople for the first time from the sea, the view of the city fom the Golden Horn being magnificent
The chief things to see in Constantinople are the Mosque of San Sophia, the Golden Horn and the Valley of Sweet Waters.

Smyrna is a thriving commercial port, at which many steamers call. Many charming excursions can be made from it; to the Cyclo-poean Cities of Nymphaeum and Sipylus and the rock-cut City of Niobe near Magnesia; the Baths of Diana and Agamemnon; and the Meles Valley, where may be seen the Chair and Cave of Homer and a fire double-arched acqueduct.

there is a railway to Ephesus where there is a good Hotel and Restaurant kept by an Englishman. The ruins of the Great Temple of Diana are about three-quarters of a mile distant. Of the "Seven churches of Asia." five are ac-cessible by tain from Smyrna. Laodicea can be reached from Alascheir which is 50 miles distant by rail and is the site of Philadelphus.
This is a beautiful old City at the foot of Mt. Tmolus; it was built in B.C. 160 by Attalus Philadelphus, last King of Pergamos.

div.head: Palestine and Syria
div.p: The nearest port from Egypt in Jaffa, the ancient Joppa. You can take steamer from Alexandria or Port Said to Jaffa or any of the Syrian ports. Probably the largest steamers on route are those of the Messageries Maritimes. There are Austrian Lloyd, and Khedivial steamers, and also occasional Moss, and Price line steamers. You must on no account forget to obtain a special passport for Palestine before leaving Egypt, or you will find much difficulty at the ports.

The landing at Jaffa is most exciting. As there is no harbour, the steamer drops anchor as near as she safely can to the shore, and large row boats come out to take off the passengers. A great reef through which there is only one small opening protects the coast, and the interesting moment is the passing through this opening in the row boat. There is not much to detain you at Jaffa, though there are two excellent hotels outside the town. There is a railway to Jerusalem, also an excellent carriage road, the drive occupying about eight hours.

The trip from Jerusalem to Jericho can be made by carriage or by riding. The drive is very fine, the views of the steep ravine of the Wady Kelt (the Book Cherith) with the monastery clinging to its side, and of the Dead Sea and Jordan Valley being very fine.

Fom Jerusalem to Damascus by land, is a camping tour of about a fortnight. The route is by Nablous - the ancient Samaritan Shechem - Jenin, Haifa, (Mount Carmel), Nazareth, Tiberias, Tell Hum (Capernaum), Safed and Banias (Caesarea Philippi). There are other camping expeditions possible from Jerusalem, as, from Jerusalem via Nazareth and Haifa, Tyre and Sidon to Beyrout, whence there is a rail to Damascus.

Conversation Saloon and Rooms at Moderate Prices. Reduced Charges to Commercial Travellers. The price is shown in each room. Excellent Restaurant and Café-Separate rooms. Baths. Carriages. English and French spoken.
J. DESENSKY, Proprietor.

div.head: HOTEL REGINA.
div.p: Very First-class. The newest and most modern Hotel of Ostend. All rooms with balconies overlooking the Sea. Concerts during Luncheons, Afternoon Teas and Dinners. Buites with Private Baths. Otis Lift. Restaurant Francais. Grill Room. American Bar. Telegrams: REGINA, OSTEND.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL MENGELLE
div.p: Lift. Rue Royale. Elevator.

First-class Hotel, in the healthiest part of the town. Excellent Cuisine. Fine Wines, and moderate Charges. Reading, Smoking, and Billiard Rooms. Sanitary arrangements of the most perfect character. Baths. Electric Light.
SCHAKE, Pere et Fils, Proprietors.

div.head: HOTEL METROPOLE.
div.p: First-class Hotel with all Modern Comfort, in the best and most central part of Brussels. 250 Bedrooms and Private Parlours. NEW WING. 60 Rooms, with Bath Rooms en suite. Splendid Palm Garden. American Bar. Steam Heating
WIELEMANS-CEUPPENS, Proprietor.
HOTEL BELLEVUE,
39, AVENUE DE L'OPERA

Finest central situation in the Capital, facing the Opera House First-rate Restaurant. Luncheon & Dinner served at small tables Reading & Smoking Rooms. Electric Light throughout. Lift. Baths. Special arrangements made for the Winter. No extra charge for Service and Light. Tel. No. 23,276: Tel. Address "Hotel Bellevue, Paris."
Mme. L. HAUSER, Proprietres.

div.head: HOTEL de la GRANDE BRETAGNE,
div.p: 14, Rue Caumartin. Near the Madeleine and Opera, in proximity of the Grand Boulevards and Gare St. Lazare: Re-decorated and re-furnished. Doulton's Sanitary Arrangements. Bedrooms from 3 francs. Apartments of all sizes. Luncheon 3 frines: Dinner 4 francs. Restaurant à la Carte, moderate prices. Excellent Cuisine and Cellar. Electric Light in the Rooms.

div.head: MIRABEAU HOTEL ET RESTAURANT,
div.p: 8, RUE DE LA PAIX, 8,
PLACE VENDOME.
PLACE DE L'OPERA
PEACE. COMFORT. EASE.
Same Management in Summer, May-October. at Chatel Guyon (Puy de Dôme), Splendid et Nouvel Hotels; and at Contrexeville (Vosges) Grand Hotel.
